text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to summarize the likely conditions in which the injunction will stand, specifically referring to four points: i) the parties have not ousted the jurisdiction of the court, ii) the assets are genuinely at risk of dissipation, iii) the relief does not duplicate or pre-empt remedies available in the arbitration, and iv) the matter is either urgent or the tribunal has given permission. The candidate answer touches upon urgency (under 'Factors Favoring Court Intervention' and 'Practical Scenarios') and the court's retained power (referencing Section 44, which implies jurisdiction isn't ousted), but it fails to explicitly address or clearly summarize the conditions related to i) ousting jurisdiction, iii) non-duplication/pre-emption, and iv) tribunal permission, as distinct required elements.", "criterion_id": "e8d6e664-29d5-4701-aa71-9393eb1482de"}
